job_title: Hospice RN Case Manager in Lakeland, FL
pros: Working with hospice patients is extremely rewarding and quite possibly the most physically and emotionally taxing job that I have held in 30 years as a full time practicing RN. The relationships you make with your families/patient will bring you to tears of joy and sorrow. Joy for your role in helping guide them in their end of life journey and sorrow as you try to comfort the loved ones left behind...all the while managing every aspect of their care and your own emotions. As a RN case manager you are their front line person and with the help/support of the social workers, chaplains, CNA's and other staff, if you are blessed to have a good team, you manage that care.
cons: Exhaustion...physical, emotional, mental. Continued IT/computer issues. To do the job correctly, you don't have any time off as you feel compelled to check emails, answer calls from your patients/families, order medications/supplies to stay ahead of supply chain demands and ensure your patient's don't go without on your days off. If you don't do it...it does not get followed through by the office staff. Bi-weekly interdisciplinary team meetings that take days of charting extra notes to prepare for. You are told to do your charting on the days you are working. NOT...there is no way to accomplish this, because when you do get home...you are charting for hours. You are monitored via phone app from the time you leave your home and on every visit you start and finish. Your appraisal and ratings/evaluations are also based on this and the system is "broken". You will work the hardest you have ever worked in your life, told you are the top performer and given a 2% increase that doesn't even cover rising gas/insurance costs. I worked a year + and did not miss ONE sick day. My partner was out continually. When I took a new job that I needed for my physical and emotional well-being, gave a 3 week notice, the company took 90 hours of my hard earned PTO and refused to pay me for it, stating I didn't work a 4 week notice. Bottom line...you will give your heart and soul to your patients/families, you will get emails of praise, but when the rubber meets the road...the company cares nothing about you as a person/employee. As long as you work, don't call in ever, cover call and the team managers never have to worry when you manage things...things seem great. When I gave my 3 week notice they did the Jekyl/Hyde and didn't stand up for me for my PTO. I couldn't in good faith take my PTO because my partner was out so much and my patient's were suffering as we tried to patch the visits with PRN's.

pros: The patients and families you work with make the challenging moments worth it
cons: Lack of support from management, no morale (no team bonding or sense of connectedness) physically and emotionally taxing and demanding.

review_title: As a seasoned Medical Social Worker, working at Cornerstone Hospice was my worst professional experience!
pros: Team-members were supportive and dedicated to patient care, but very fearful of openly addressing clinical and ethical concerns, due to fear of retribution, up to and including termination, by Direct Supervisor and Regional Team Manager, whose favoritism, bullying behavior, and micromanagement style aligned with the company's overall culture.
cons: Management, to include HR, creates, encourages, supports and maintains a culture of behavior marked by unethical practices that are not in the best interest of the clients/families and/or the employees, ineffective communication and conflict resolution (i.e. employees who bring concerns to HR's attention are scapegoated as the problem. Therefore, the core issues are never resolved, which maintains the culture's status quo), and a lack of work-life balance, which is encouraged and rewarded. Patient/family quality care is not high on the priority list, and neither is employee support and satisfaction. Management is incompetent, lacks integrity, and a sense of fairness, does not take responsibility, and has no standards, thereby allowing management to change the rules on a whim, to suit them. The pay is the lowest and the stress is the highest! It's a revolving door: I was the fourth employee in my position over the span of 2 years! If you are amoral, unethical, and/or a person with no integrity or self-respect, who will do anything to remain employed, this is the job for you.

pros: Wonderful families.  You meet nice staff too, but they don't stay because the company is so corrupt.
cons: Corrupt company.  The education department is a joke.  People get admitted and they don't even know what hospice is.  People are not getting their pain controlled.  Nurses with no hospice experience are hired, then they are put out in the field to the patient's detriment.  They admit non-appropriate hospice patients to get the Medicare dollars, then discharge after one certification period.  It is so sad.

review_title: Management is awful. Every new person they add is worse than the last. They have lost focus on the patient.
pros: Helping the terminally ill and their families.
cons: Management is aggressive. Human resources is so improperly managed it is unbelievable. No raises for years but start new hires out at higher wages.

review_title: Serious Concerns with Knowledge of Leadership and Their Integrity

cons: Very poor leadership.  Upper management clearly presents a lack of integrity and understanding of what hospice should be.  Lower management tells employees that despite unethical and sometimes insane directives, failure to follow through could result in being fired.
